div.head: Invited Paper
div.p: This paper provides an overview of the taxonomy theory which has been proposed as a fundamental platform for solving practical stability related problems in large constrained nonlinear systems such as the electric power system. The theory reveals a two-level intertwined cellular nature of the constrained system dynamics which serves as a unifying structure, a taxonomy, for analyzing nonlinear phenomena in large system models. These broadly divide into the state sjiace aspects (related to dynamic stability issues among others) and the parameter space aspects (connected with bifurcation phenomena among others). In the state-space formulation, the boundary of the region of attraction for the operating point is shown (under certain Morse-hale like assumptions) to be composed of stable manifolds of certain anchors and portions of the singularity surface. Such boundary characterization provides the foundation for rigorous Lyapunov theoretic transient stability methods. In the parameter space analysis, the feasibility region which is bounded by the feasibility boundary provides a safe operating region for guaranteeing local stability at the equilibrium under slow parametric variations. The feasibility boundary where the operating point undergoes loss of local stability is characterized in the form of three principal bifurcations including a new bifurcation called the singularity induced bifurcation. An overview of the recent results which prove that the two-level structure exists even in nonmsooth models that incorporate the effects of system hard limits is also included. SpecGcally hard limits induce a number of new bifurcations. This natural taxonomy of the system dynamics stands as the backbone for developing practical and rigorous computational techniques in detecting diverse instability mechanisms.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: The objective of this research, ongoing now for more than a decade, is to develop a mathematically precise and physically meaningful theory for the large constrained nonlinear dynamic systems with a clear structure of the details and the interactions throughout the state and parameter spaces-a taxonomy. The mathematical theory for large differentialalgebraic systems (DAE's in short) as separate from power system specifics is presented in Section IV with an overview in Section 11.

A brief history of recent nonlinear phenomena in power system analysis is presented now with special emphasis on constrained power system models. More extensive citations appear throughout the text on relevant subject areas.

The first major step in the direction of developing a stability theory was a systematic analysis in [141, [651, [921, 1931 of the large nonlinear (unconstrained) smooth system in a MorseSmale like formulation, which observed the composition of the stability boundary. As in the Morse-Smale theory 1441, [57], a stratification of the stability boundary as a union of the stable manifolds of unstable equilibria (in a descending order) was proved in 1931 while the explicit contribution to the boundary analysis from the presence of periodic orbits was established in [ 141. A novel concept of a "quasistability boundary" was introduced in [92], [93] which eliminated impractical interior segments of the boundary and by so doing importantly simplified the analysis and engineering use of the boundary. Specifically based on the concept of the quasistability boundary, it was proved in [93] that it is sufficient to consider only the order one unstable equilibrium points (the type one equilibria) for precise and practical analysis of the stability boundary.

In the parameter space analysis, a static notion of feasible regions was proposed in [37] introducing the concept of regions as a tool in analyzing the general feasibility of load-flow solutions. Significance of nonlinear dynamic phenomena such as bifurcations in smooth unconstrained power system models was identified in [ 11 which studied the occurrence of Hopf bifurcations, while other early works [38], [51] analyzed global bifurcations and complex behavior in angle-stability models. On the voltage side, the relationship between the singularity of the load-flow Jacobian, proximity to multiple load-flow solutions and voltage instability phenomena was recognized in [63], [66], and the precise mathematical connection between these three events was established in [40] using the Sotomayor theory of the saddle node bifurcation [59]. Reference [40] also observed the occurrence of a special bifurcation arising in a constrained power system model related to the noncausal nature of the algebraic constraints.

The importance of the differential-algebraic formulation in voltage stability studies was demonstrated in [90] where several new phenomena were introduced related to the singular points (called noncausal points in [40]). These include observations in small-scale power system models on new contributions to the stability boundary from certain special singular points and the presence of certain bifurcations directly connected with the singularity. The interaction of the state space and the parameter space with initial beginnings of a taxonomy were presented in [99] on some minimum size power system models.

The constrained nature of detailed power system models has been well known in power system analysis. For instance, [94] and [7, Section 9.21 state the dynamic problem as a "coupled" set of differential equations, coupling via the power-flow equations and variables. Explicit models of the constrained nature were introduced in [I21 for transient stability analysis of nonconstant-impedance type load models. These "nonclassical" power system models were given the name "structure preserving power system models" [12], [34] which directly reflected the network structure of the power system in the form of algebraic equations within the model.

There exists a rich history of "direct" stability methods based on energy function concepts and Lyapunov theoretic tools [29], [43], [50]. Development of Lyapunov theoretic techniques to constrained power system models can be seen in [34], [42]. An extensive Lyapunov stability theory for DAE systems has been proposed in [32], [34] where some effects of singular points (called impasse points in [34]) are considered. Recent work in [48] uses Lyapunov theory tools [34], the stability boundary characterization [68] and the static bifurcation properties of the singularity in deriving transient stability algorithms for DAE models.

The first detailed geometric analysis of a rudimentary constrained power system model was carried out in [67], [73] where the rich interactions of the state space features (such as those related to the singularity) and parameter space phenomena (including the occurrence of several local and global bifurcations) were rigorously analyzed. Moreover it was proved that these individual details indeed fit in nicely as an overall structure, what we later called the taxonomy in [68]. Reference [67] included an analysis of a special local bifurcation which arises when an equilibrium crosses the singularity called the singularity induced bifurcation and a new global bifurcation called the singularity connection bifurcation [67] where periodic orbits were annihilated. The full fledged taxonomy theory for analyzing the dynamics of large differential-algebraic nonlinear models was presented in [68], [71], [72]. A precise two level intertwined cellular structure for each of the state space and the parameter space was proved there.

In a more general sense, DAE models have been analyzed in singular control theory with applications in robotics [ 131 among other areas. Differential-algebraic systems have also been studied with much interest in nonlinear network theory. Reference [52] analyzed certain jump phenomena in singularly perturbed large scale models, while [ 181 proved that in general large DAE's, impasse points where the trajectories of differential-algebraic equations cannot be continued are generic within the set of all singular points.

In mathematical theory [60] first posed the problem of special phenomena arising in constrained nonlinear systems. Jump phenomenon in a class of constrained gradient vector fields was analyzed in [61] which also studied the generic dynamic structure near certain singular points in two and three dimensional systems. Later mathematical works in this context appear to be focused on the concept of canards which are complicated jump phenomena leading to duck cycles or canard oscillations [21]. Canards occur near certain special singular points under singular perturbations of the DAE models. These methods are based on nonstandard mathematical analysis [ 1011, and are restricted to two and three dimensional systems [lo], [21].

Around 1990, we and others started systematically investigating large nonlinear systems modeled by differential equations with algebraic equality conditions (DAE's) [90], [99]. The authors have since proceeded to develop a currently nearly complete theory which was introduced in [68] under the name of a "taxonomy"' which is the topic of this paper. The taxonomy theory in [68], [71], [72] is a theory of very large scope (includes something like 25 major theorems and hundreds of lemmas) which covers both the state and parameter spaces for DAE's, and in its most recent developments [84] also for large systems with many different types of system hard limits. In the Taxonomy theory, all major and minor analytical and structural aspects of these classes of systems are analyzed in detail. The theory for the DAE case is summarized in Section V with a brief synopsis of the hard limit version in Section VI. Section VI also summarizes recent results by others tied to this theory.

Analysis of the state and parameter spaces for large constrained nonlinear systems in this work have revealed that both these spaces have a two-level cellular structure (in the form of regions and subregions) in a topological sense. This structure is summarized below for the DAE case.

Briefly the state space is divided at the upper level by the singular surface into open components so that the constrained dynamics restricted to individual components is smooth. However the trajectories when reaching the component boundaries namely the singularity surface typically undergo loss of existencehniqueness, hence lose analytical tractability in the sense of the DAE model. The components in turn contain possibly several stability regions and other instability regions in the lower level of for papers [102].

the state space structure. Among these subregions of a component, the dominant and most interesting region is the region of attraction of the stable operating point. It is proved that the boundary of the region of attraction (under certain Morse-Smale like assumptions) consists among other segments some which derive from the singularity surface itself and also from stable manifolds anchored at special very high dimensional subsets of the singularity surface.

The parameter space at the upper level is divided into feasibility regions of various operating points by the feasibility boundaries. Operating points cannot cross the feasibility boundaries without losing their local stability in a generic sense. The feasibility boundary consists of three types of principal bifurcation segments including a new bifurcation called the singularity induced bifurcation which was first rigorously studied by us in [68]. The subregions in the parameter space are called by us the typal regions because the state space topology is uniform at all parameter values within these typal regions. The boundaries of the typal regions consist of local bifurcations and global bifurcations.

Within the taxonomy theory of DAE's, a special role is played by the singularity both in the form of singular boundaries in the state space and in the form of bifurcations connected with the singularity in the parameter space. The complexity encountered accordingly in the study of these is a major aspect of the work reported here. New bifurcations both local and global are observed here and are precisely analyzed (Sections V and VI) [68], [72], [84]. The singularity and its neighborhood, a difficult area mostly neglected in the literature, has been analyzed thoroughly with a rich classification of subsets of the singularity (such as transverse singular points, nice pseudo-equilibria and nice semi-singular points, and the bad subsets) [68], [721. The local and global properties are established for the singular system by globally transforming the singular vector field of the DAE into a smooth vector field which preserves the topology of the state space and the parameter space and this formulation is a novel contribution of our work [68], [72]. Analysis of these matters reveals many detailed questions which must be answered before a precise description of these major structural elements is possible. All this amounts to a theory of very large scope [68], [72], [84] that is presented in a condensed form in Sections V and VI. It is offered as the solid foundation for continuing research in this area, and as the basis and starting point for engineeringkomputational solutions of practical problems. The authors and others are now engaged in work on these areas.

Application of the feasibility boundary aspects of the theory (related to the occurrence of the supercritical Hopf bifurcation and the birth of sustained oscillations) was recently completed by us in [89] for computational analysis of a very large (about 7500 buses) power system subject to a real life disturbance. This recent effort by the authors encourages further development of large system computational algorithms based on the taxonomy theory making this theory a practical tool for stability analysis of the large power system.

The organization of the paper is as follows. In Section 11, we summarize the mathematical aspects of the large DAE models while Section 111 is specifically connected with the operational aspects of the electric power system. Section IV introduces the singularity aspects of the DAE problem through a simple rudimentary power system example. Section V presents the salient features of the taxonomy theory for the dynamics of large DAE systems in the form of several theorems and lemmas. Section VI reports some of the recent extensions to the theory by others and by us.

div.head: A. Local Stability Issues
div.p: When the parameters p are varied, it is intuitively clear that the quantitative behavior of the trajectories of the model C will be different. However, when we consider system operation at a stable operating point, we can demand that the condition of small-signal stability or local stability at the operating point be preserved under parametric variations (such as under slow load variations) so that continued system operation at the equilibrium point is feasible. This motivates a notion of feasibility region in the parameter space as the set of all operating points in the parameter space which can be reached by quasistatic parametric variations during the system operation. This region then naturally identifies a safe operating region in the parameter space within which the operation can be shifted around freely (by slow continuous parameter changes) without an imminent danger of losing local stability or small-signal stability. Of course, it has to be remembered that typically the size of the region of attraction (roughly the size of the stability domain) decreases down to zero as one approaches the feasibility boundary, therefore the proximity to the feasibility boundary (the boundary of the feasibility region) could also imply potential emergence of transient instability problems. In other words, while the system operation has to stay inside the feasibility region for sustained local stability, it is also desirable that it stays well inside the region and away from the boundary to lessen the danger of transient instability phenomena.

All this demands a careful analysis of the feasibility boundary for gaining insight into its structure and for developing computational methods. These matters are summarized in the first level of Table 1. It can be shown (see Section V-(2.2) that the boundary of the feasibility region typically consists of three types of bifutcation surfaces, namely the saddle node, Hopf, and a special type of bifurcation which only arises in constrained models of the form C called by us the singularity induced bifurcation (Section V-C.2). Identification of these bifurcation boundaries either by eigenvalue computations (such as by using the EPRI program SSSP) or by other direct means [56] (see point of collapse methods [6] and continuation algorithms [4]) provides us with the means for computing the boundary of feasible system operation. Our team has recently developed effective computational techniques for the feasibility boundary computation in large scale systems [89] using the results in this paper.

div.head: B. Global Stability Issues
div.p: The primary question in global stability issues is connected with determining whether the trajectory starting from an initial condition say zo will converge to a stable equilibrium point say xS. Therefore the limits of global stability are defined by the boundary of the region of attraction or simply the stability boundary for z, (the lower level in Table 2). More details on the stability boundary analysis follow in Section V-C.

div.head: In. AN OVERVIEW OF POWER SYSTEM OPERATION ISSUES
div.p: The objective of the large power system is to economically generate and to distribute power to its customers through transmission and distribution networks with standard quality of service meaning that voltages, currents and frequency are within appropriate tolerances (this quality is called here the viability of the system and is also called the acceptability in the power engineering literature) and as free as possible of disturbances, oscillations, etc. Planning designs the system for being able to be operated viably under most circumstances and to minimize the number and seventy of cases when such normal operation is not possible.

Changing conditions and disturbances are always a possibility and the system is very large indeed with states ranging in the tens and hundreds of thousands. Typically every transmission line and every generator is different, unlike even larger telephone and computer systems where identical components are present by the millions. The time scales of the dynamic events considered here range widely: the fast range of the voltage and angular transient stability roughly from 10 ms to 10 s, medium range of automatic generation control (AGC) involving speed governors, turbines, and boilers in the minutes, and much slower even seasonal for hydrostorage.

Our personal motivation for these studies comes from the power system and mostly its fast and medium range dynamics. Nevertheless most of the results are applicable to any large nonlinear DAE system, and such DAE problems will also occur across all time ranges of the power system. Accordingly the presentation in Sections V and VI is in general terms although the power system interactions and motivations are stated throughout. Some of the general issues connected with the power system will now be pointed out.

div.head: A. Region of Security
div.p: There are numerous optimization problems in the power system such as the economic dispatch of generation, energy management systems (EMS), automatic generation control (AGC), and the optimal power flow (OPF) among many others. Load forecasting and generation scheduling form another crucial area. However the bottom-line is the security of the operation and we will take our motivation from there in this paper.

The power system is secure if it has regions of feasibility, viability, and transient stability of adequate shape and size either 1) to assure continued system operation or 2) return of the system to the operating point, or 3) (in case of equipment loss) the shift to an alternate feasible, viable and transiently stable equilibrium point following any "first contingency" from a prespecified set of first contingencies. Furthermore the following definitions apply.
1) Viability, i.e., all voltages, currents, frequency, etc., are within the applicable tolerances. This defines an open viability region, V, in the parameter space.

2 ) Feasibility, i.e., the operating point exists as a stable equilibrium which is continuously movable as such over an open feasibility region, F , in the parameter and state space. 3) Transient stability, i.e., when subjected to any of a specified set of contingencies, trajectories converge back to a stable operating point from any state within an open region of transient stability in the state space. In other words, the region of security, i.e., safe operating region is defined as the intersection of the regions of viability, transient stability and feasibility. Our attention here will be devoted primarily to feasibility and transient stability since viability has no direct dynamic features.

Note that "transient stability" is a special and traditional term in the power system in that it depends on a set of specified contingencies. This term will be used in its traditional meaning within this paper. Specifically an equilibrium point say 2, is transient stable if the system converges back to a viable stable equilibrium condition after it is subjected to any one of a specified set of first contingencies. This of course happens if the post-contingency initial state lies within the region of attraction of a suitable stable equilibrium point for the post-contingency parameter values. This postulates a knowledge of the stability boundary of the relevant region of attraction for checking transient stability which is difficult problem analytically and computationally. However transient stability can be evaluated without knowing the stability boundary by numerically computing the post-contingency trajectories.

A very large effort is in progress in the literature (more than a thousand papers) to "bypass" the trajectory computation or the finding of the stability boundary by various approximations often connected with Lyapunov theory, to estimate the minimum distance, the dynamic security margin, from the post-contingency state to the stability boundary. This paper is not directly connected with this part of the literature. In the paper, the emphasis is on establishing the precise structure of the stability boundary. Equipped with this knowledge of boundary composition, viable approximations of the boundary can be developed using Lyapunov theoretic tools. Some developments in this direction [48] will be discussed in Section VI. In what follows, we will see that dynamic stability problems (both numerical and analytical ones) are naturally related to the dynamic structure shown in Table 1.

div.head: B. Validity of the Quasi-Stationary Phasor Models
div.p: The differential-algebraic model C based on the phasor representation for the transmission network is indeed an excellent model for studying dynamic phenomena provided the variations of the phasor state variables are much slower than that of the carrier (that is, for studying dynamic phenomena which are much slower with respect to the 60 Hz carrier frequency). This traditional assumption known as the quasistationary (or quasistatic) phasor approximation is a fundamental limitation in the DAE power system model and it cannot be ignored in the analysis of E.

In [68], [SI], [96], we have observed the limitations connected with conventional quasistationary lumped parameter RLC models for the transmission lines in the DAE phasor formulation. The lumped parameter transmission line model is indeed a good approximation in analysis for dynamics not faster than those in the common transient stability variety [96]. However, many of the emerging (thyristor based) voltage control actions and some of the voltage stability phenomena are so fast that the quasistationary assumption which is the basis for the traditional DAE phasor model simply loses validity. The DAE formulation implies instantaneous dynamics of the transmission lines (resulting in the algebraic phasor power flow (2)) and so it neglects the fast electromagenetic transients within the transmission lines.

Recently by using a novel notion of fast balanced timevarying phasors [81], an extensive analysis in [79], [84] has proved that the precise model for the balanced power system (with distributed parameter type line models) is one of differential equations for the equipment (generators, loads, etc.) constrained by algebraic equations with line specific time-delays for the transmission network. When the lines are short and for sufficiently slow dynamics, the effects of these time delays can be neglected as an approximation thus yielding the conventional power flow equations. However, for studying faster phenomena such as for the behavior near the singularity and for understanding the trajectory behavior In this section, we will focus on a simple power system model studied in [67], [73], E901 which serves as an excellent platform for introducing the special nonlinear phenomena in DAE models. We want to emphasize that the two-dimensional (2-0) model example used in this section is only meant to be for illustrative purposes and the theory to be presented in Section V i s applicable for systems of any size that is for the general large system. Assumptions like the generator dynamics in (5)-( 7) and on load models in (10) and (1 1) apply only to this section and should not be inferred to the general discussion. The rudimentary power system model CZ to be introduced in Section IV-A has the advantage that the constrained dynamic properties can be readily displayed graphically in the form of comprehensive numerical simulations [73]. Moreover, the structure of the dynamics observed for this model in Section IV-B on the state space properties does carry over to the large system as established in Section V. We will also return to the DAE example Cz in later sections for additional illustrations.

It becomes necessary to consider more detailed system models for describing the dynamics 08 the manifold L ("beyond" the singular points) and the nature of these models would depend on the actual physical system under study. For nonlinear circuits for instance, singularly perturbed dynamic models emerge when the parasitic effects of circuit capacitances and inductances are included in the model [lS], [52]. However, in the electric power system, questions on the dynamics off the constraint set L are far more challenging to analyze since the quasistationary assumption which is the fundamental building block of phasor dynamic representation used in DAE power system models loses its validity in these domains (see Section 111-B) and hence the singular points should be considered as transitions to unpredictable behavior in power system models [68]. At the special singular point $, two different trajectories of C2 seem to crisscross each other at $ and hence the DAE system behavior is even more complex.

Some of the singular points (above $ in Fig. 2) act as "sources" of two trajectories while some other singular points (below $ in Fig. 2) act as ''sinks'' of two trajectories and the special singular point $ in Fig. 2 separates the two different types of singular points. In Section V-A, we prove that this source-sink nature of the singularity is in fact preserved in general large system models E. The source-like singular points are precisely defined "transverse sources" and the sink-like singular points are defined "transverse sinks" in Section V-A. The special point $ which has an interesting characteristic that the trajectories near $ behave like near a saddle point of a smooth system is indeed proved to possess dynamic properties like a saddle point and is defined a pseudo-saddle in Section V-A.

The main difference in large systems compared to the rudimentary power system in Fig. 2 is that each of these subsets namely transverse sources, transverse sinks and pseudo-saddles emerge as very high dimensional surfaces: (n -1)-dimensional, (n -1)-dimensional, and (n -2)-dimensional manifolds, respectively, within an ndimensional constraint set L. There exist two regions of attraction in the state space of Fig. 2 for the two stable equilibrium points xi and xi, respectively. For the DAE model C2 in Fig. 2, the regions of attraction of the two stable equilibria xi and z j are clearly subsets of the state space components LFhlgh and LFl,,, respectively, and the boundaries of the regions of attraction consist of singular points together with trajectories converging to the special point +. Specifically for the stable equilibrium (which is the normal operating point), the boundary of the region of attraction for lc; (the stability boundary) consists of the singular source points on a -$ above the point $ in Fig. 2 and the trajectory in the component L F h l g h that converges to the point $ from below point $ in Fig. 2. A similar structure exists for the region of attraction of the other stable equilibrium xe in Fig. 2.

Note that the trajectory originating from an initial condition (for instance, the post-contingency state in power system transient stability studies) within the region of attraction for xi converges to the operating point zS, thus resulting in normal system operation. On the other hand, if the initial condition (or the post-contingency state) is outside the region of attraction for xi (e.g., anywhere in the component LFl,, in Fig. 2) then the trajectory will not converge to the operating point xi thus possibly leading to voltage collapse and system breakup.

In Fig. 2, we observe that the structure of the stability boundaries for the two equilibria xi and xj are quite similar. That is, the stability boundary for either equilibrium in Fig. 2 is a union of 1) certain singular source points, and 2) the trajectory converging to the pseudo-saddle point $. In fact, we prove in Section V-B that the stability boundary in the n-dimensional large system model C can consist of ((n -1)-dimensional) singular sources as well as the trajectories converging to ((n -2)-dimensional) pseudo-saddles. Moreover, there can exist additional types of singular points called nice semi-singular points and bad pseudo-equilibrium points on the stability boundary together with stable manifolds of regular unstable equilibria and of smooth unstable periodic orbits. Full details on the stability boundary for DAE models follow in Section V-B. We need to remark at this point that the stability status of the low voltage equilibrium xe (observed as a small-signal stable equilibrium in Fig. 2) demands a careful scrutiny in a real power system as related to the fast dynamics off the constraint set L which has not been considered so far in the DAE model C [102]. Detailed discussions on this topic of dynamics outside the DAE domain of C in power system models are available in [68], [84].

In summary, we observe from Fig. 2 that the singular points can drastically influence the trajectories of the DAE system since the validity of the DAE model typically breaks down at singular points. Structurally, singular points are significant a) in dividing the constrained state space L into open components (upper level of the state space structure in Table 2), and b) in bounding the region of attraction of a stable equilibrium (lower level of the DAE state space structure in Table 2). Similarly the singular points play fundamental roles in determining the parameter space structure leading to the birth of local and global bifurcations in the DAE model and a comprehensive analysis for the DAE model C2 is presented in [73]. However, owing to space limitations, we will not discuss the details of the singularity related parameter space phenomena in this section.

div.p: In this section, we summarize the salient mathematical results of the large DAE system C and numerical simulations for the simple DAE model C2 are used to illustrate the concepts. An analysis of the main structural features of the constrained dynamics with emphasis on those aspects which are caused by the presence of the algebraic constraints is given in Section V-A. Since the analysis of the overall structure in Section V-A is necessary for both the state space analysis of stability regions and the parameter space analysis of bifurcations, these issues are treated separately in Section V-A. The structure of the parameter space is summarized in Section V-C. The concept of a feasibility region is defined. The singularity induced bifurcation, which arises when the equilibrium is at the singularity, is rigorously analyzed in Sections V-C.3 and V-C.4. A brief introduction to the concept of typal regions is presented in Section V-C.5.

In this paper we present the theory in a more tutorial fashion. All the proofs are published in the form of a technical report [72] and in several of our publications [68], [70], [71], [77], [go]. In this paper, we only summarize the salient results.

div.head: C. Structure of the Parameter Space
div.p: The parameter space can be broadly divided (functionally) into the set of all system parameters (which do not change during system operation) and the set of operating parameters (that can change during operation). When these parameters change, the state space (consisting of system trajectories or transients) associated with each parameter value undergoes changes, however the structure of the state space remains topologically equivalent unless we encounter certain boundaries in the parameter space, namely the bifurcation boundaries. In other words, the bifurcation surfaces in the parameter space divide the parameter space into open connected regions called the typal regions [67], [68] within which the structure of the state space remains identical. This includes the static properties such as the equilibrium structure, dynamic local, properties such as the stability status of equilibria, and dynamic global properties such as the composition of the stability boundary. Therefore this knowledge on the properties of typal regions would provide us with a sort of "complete" overview of the current system operation for security studies. However at the present time, such an overview ,seems to be impossible even theoretically for large nonlinear systems. This is because the boundary of the typal regions consists of local and global bifurcations. Specifically the global bifurcations in general can themselves be dense in open sets of the parameter space [9], [30] (complex behavior), which then renders the problem extremely difficult to analyze even for systems in dimension three, let alone the large system. For these reasons, we restrict the analysis in this section to the study of a simpler yet more practical concept in the parameter space called the notion of feasibility regions.

The concept of feasibility regions in the solution space of nonlinear problems has existed for a long time (for instance, in optimization theory). In the power system context, Jargis and Galiana [37] introduced a notion of load-flow feasibility for quantifying the solvability of the load-flow equations in the parameter space. Later work of Fischl et al. 1281 extended this concept to include the effects of small-signal stability by restricting the analysis to those solutions where the system is small-signal stable. The boundary of this region then consists of points where an operating point undergoes change in its eigenstructure, and these points therefore correspond to local bifurcations. In unconstrained system models, it is well known that the generic local bifurcations are the saddle-node bifurcation (connected with zero eigenvalue of the system Jacobian) and the Hopf bifurcation (related to purely imaginary eigenvalues of the system Jacobian). The first case of zero eigenvalues and the saddle-node bifurcation has been studied extensively in the recent past connected with the voltage collapse phenomena. The Hopf bifurcation can be generally associated with oscillatory phenomena [78], [SO] leading to either stable oscillations (supercritical Hopf [30]) or oscillatory divergence (subcritical Hopf [30]). Recently, occurrences of oscillatory voltage disturbances have been reported by the industry, even though this phenomenon is not well understood in general. There has been extensive research progress recently 141, [6], [23], 1261 on the problem of computing the nearest saddle-node and Hopf bifurcation points in the parameter space.

In 1671, [68], we have proposed a notion of feasibility region in the parameter space as the set of all operating points in the parameter space which can be reached by quasistatic parametric variations as part of the system operation. This region then naturally identifies a safe operating region in the parameter space within which the operation can be shifted around freely (by slow continuous parameter changes) without an imminent danger of losing local stability. Of course, it has to be remembered that the size of the region of attraction (roughly the size of the region of transient stability) decreases down to zero as one approaches the feasibility boundary (see Loss of Stability Theorem [72], and Section IV-C. 1), therefore the proximity to the feasibility boundary, that is the boundary of the feasibility region, could indicate potential emergence of transient instability problems. So in summary, while the system operation has to stay inside the feasibility region for sustained small-signal stability, it is also desirable to stay well inside the region and away from the boundary to lessen the danger of transient instability phenomena. All this demands a careful analysis of the feaGbility boundary for gaining insight into its structure and for developing techniques to compute them.
We will show that the boundary of the feasibility region as defined here typically consists of three types of

div.p: A feasibility region consists of possibly several open subregions, called typal regions in this paper, and some of the respective boundaries. Typal regions are defined by the property that the phase-portraits of the system are topologically equivalent (i.e., structurally stable) within one subregion. The boundaries between these regions are determined by various local and global bifurcation surfaces. The possibility of complex behavior connected with global bifurcations has been noted in angle [38], [51] and voltage [15], [67], [86] power system models. Specifically global bifurcations related to chaotic power system behavibr have received much attention recently [2],

[SI, [151, 1381, 1.511, [671, [731, [861. All these papers analyze complex behavior in certain small-scale power system models. For the large system, there exist but a few analytical results [88] on global bifurcations. In [75], a computational method for tracking homoclinic bifurcations (which may lead to complicated behavior upon perturbations) was proposed using center manifold theory and normal form theory by analyzing certain interior feasibility boundary segments.

For the rudimentary power system model defined in Section IV-A (with n = 2 and m = 1 in (1) and ( 2 ) ) , a complete classification of the typal regions has been given in [67], [73] for a realistic range of two parameters (power and control). However, for a general n-dimensional system defined by (1) and (2), for reasons of dimensionality and because of the difficulty connected with complex system behavior, a similar complete typal description is unrealistic.

div.head: VI. RECENT EXTENSIONS
div.p: In this section, we summarize some recent developments on the stability analysis of large scale constrained systems. The first subsection summarizes riesults from [34], [48] which provide global ODE representations of the DAE model by restricting the analysis to suitable subsets in the state space. Using this concept and by carrying out static bifurcation analysis of the singularity, a Lyapunov theory based security monitoring algorithm has been proposed in [48] which is summarized in Section VI-B. Section IV-C provides an overview of recent developments presented in [84] on the dynamics of hard constrained large nonlinear systems.

div.head: A. Reduction of the DAE System to an ODE System
div.p: The objective in this section is to "reduce" the constrained dynamic problem C into a set of differential equations in the dynamic Therefore for analysis within such sets C, we can restate the DAE C (restricted to C) as j: = f ( z , h ( z ) ) .

Note that the proof of this Theorem is merely by showing the existence of the function h ( z ) whereas the construction of such functions is a far more challenging task. Mainly this result is powerful in simplifying the analysis as has been demonstrated for the Lyapunov arguments in [34], [48]. We summarize the results from [48] in the next subsection.

div.head: B. Lyapunov Theoretic Algorithms [481
div.p: In Section V, a geometric analysis of the singular dynamics was carried out which among other things established a hierarchy of the local behavior near the singular dynamics (see Theorem 1) [68]. The results include proving that transverse singular points appear as the most nondegenerate points within the set of singular points. Among the nontransverse singular points, it was proved that nice sernsingular points and nice pseudo-equilibria emerge as the most nondegenerate from the viewpoint of local dynamics. In other words, the singular dynamics hierarchy which was presented as Theorem 1 in Section V is based on the local behavior of the dynamics near the singular points. Specifically since we restricted our attention to what goes on within the constraint set L, the geometry of the constraint surface L itself in the sense of the whole state space Rn+" near the singular points was not studied by us for the large system C.

In general, the shape of the constraint surface near the singularity could provide us with additional insight on the static structure of the singularity in the sense of the solution properties of the constraint equations g(z;y) = 0 for eliminating the y variables. By this we mean for instance, the problem of determining when the singular points occur on folds of the surface L, and when they arise as cusps on the surface L [41]. In [67], [73], a 2-D rudimentary power system model was analyzed by us where it was observed that transverse singular points and the nice pseudo-equilibrium points occur on folds of the 2-D constraint manifold. In [69], a 2-D example was presented as an illustration where it was shown that nice semi-singular points occur on cusps of the constraint surface L. However the main objective in Section V was the analysis of the dynamics C restricted to the constraint set L, and for this problem, the shape of the constraint surface L is not of direct relevance.

Recent work [48] establishes the precise relationship between the static singularity concepts such as folds and cusps which were studied in [S2] for analyzing the global jump phenomena in singularly perturbed models, and the dynamic classification of the singularity such as transverse singular points, pseudo-equilibria and semi-singular points proposed in 1681, 1721. The m a n results from [48] are stated below as a Proposition in a more general form and these results follow by direct extensions of the respective arguments in [48].

Proposition 1: For the DAE model C, the transverse singular points and nice pseudo-equilibria generically occur on folds of the constraint surface L. Nice semi-singular points cannot be present on folds of L and generically occur on cusps of the constraint surface L.

Using these results, a Lyapunov theoretic stability monitoring algorithm is proposed in [48] for a constrained power system model introduced in [34]. Since the Proposition above shows that semi-singular points generically arise as higher codimension (codimension two cusps) static bifurcations of the constraint surface L compared to the pseudo-equilibria which are generically codimension one static bifurcations (folds) of L, it is argued that semisingular points are more degenerate for the boundary analysis compared to the pseudo-equilibria. Using a Lyapunov function from [34], a constrained minimization algorithm is proposed in 1481 which identifies the "nearest" pseudoequilibrium points on the stability boundary for computing the dynamic security energy margins.

div.head: C. Hard Constraints or Hard Limits in Large Nonlinear Systems
div.p: In analyzing large physical systems which is the objective of this study, we need to consider hard limits which are always present (in very large numbers) in a real physical system. The significance of analyzing these hard limits has been emphasized in recent committee reports on voltage stability [ 1051, [ 1061 and an extensive coverage of modeling the hard limits in power system stability analysis can be seen in [39]. Recent papers in the power system literature [25], [3S], [SS] have analyzed certain instability phenomena arising from encountering the hard limits in specific system models.

In a general sense and functionally these hard limits can be divided into three basic types [84], namely 1) the actuation limits (or the windup limiters in IEEE power literature [39], [103], [104]), 2) state limits (or the nonwindup limiters in IEEE power terminology 1391, [103], [104]), and 3) switching type limits (or the relay type limits in power terminology). These are briefly introduced below from a conceptual viewpoint:

The windup limits or actuation limits <are hard limits which appear in the internal transfer of certain variables such as control errors which are functions of some states and have an internal actuating role. These hard limits do not directly affect state variables (unlike the nonwindup limits as we see below in item 2), rather the effect is through the overall dynamics. Specifically the input to such a device could "wind-up" while the output is stuck at a limit, hence the name the windup limits. These limits can be modeled in the system by introducing internal actuation variables say z, = h,(z,p) for some function h, so that z, is strictly limited between a maximum value say zu, and a minimum value say ze,. (see Section V-C.1) [39], L84.1, [1031. Nonwindup limits or state limits are functionally quite different from the windup limits since a nonwindup limit directly affects the status of a state variable. That is, when a state with a nonwindup limit reaches its limit, the state variable gets "stuck" at this limit value until the dynamics drives the state to move away from the limit value. In other words, when a nonwindup limit is encountered, and is active (the "free" dynamics is trying to push the state past the limit), then the state variable becomes a constant in the model, and the system loses a degree of freedom (system dimension in the sense of dynamics drops by one). Note that this state variable stuck at the nonwindup limit will indeed return to be an unconstrained variable the moment the "free" dynamics allows it to do so. Hence there is no windup of the state involved here. The state variable is strictly limited between its limiting values at all times hence the name state limit. The state limits can be formulated by suitably modifying the respective state derivative terms to become zero when the limits are reached and are active [391, [841, 11031. 3) In the case of switching limits, reaching the limits initiates preprogrammed structural action which then in turn can change the whole system, its state and/or parameter space. These switching actions are initiated by relay mechanisms and protective limiters in the physical system, which monitor certain states (or certain functions of several states) of the system and depending on their preprogrammed logic, take protective actions when certain (disruptive) events are sensed. For the power system, detailed models for including the effects of relays in system dynamic studies have been recently proposed in [46], [47]. Essentially the relay elements can be included in the analysis by modeling their internal logic mechanisms as state dynamic equations. In general, the switching type limits can be modeled by introducing certain internal variables say s, = i j 2 ( z , p ) where the function v,(x,p) takes only two values either zero or one [47], [84]. Each of these hard limits can be introduced into the DAE model resulting in an overall system representation which is of a hard constrained set of differential-algebraic equations. By separately considering the three types individually, it can be shown [84] that the two-level cellular structure of the DAE dynamics introduced in Sections I-V is preserved in this case.

Here we briefly discuss some aspects of this two-level cellular structure in the parameter space which consists of feasibility regions in the first level and the typal regions in second level. Let us start with the construction of the feasibility regions. Then we will analyze its bifurcation structure and show that there exist new bifurcation types on the feasibility boundary which arise when some of the hard limits are encountered under parametric variations.

In general, encountering the actuation limits either 1) may imply sustained local stability at the operating point, or 2) may lead to local bifurcations which disrupt local stability (called actuation limit induced bifurcations). The first case 1) then corresponds to interior points within the feasibility region whereas the latter case implies a boundary for feasible operation at the equilibrium. Therefore one of the main problems in local stability analysis of systems with constraints is to construct methods for distinguishing between the two types. In what follows, we develop such methods, for the case of actuation (wind-up) limits, in the form of several Theorems.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: A systematic theory for large scale nonlinear systems which are constrained either 1) by smooth algebraic equality conditions or 2) by nonsmooth hard limits of the various types including the actuation (windup) limits, state (nonwindup) limits, and the relay type (switching type) limits, is currently being developed by the authors under the name of a taxonomy. The theory covers most of the varied dynamic phenomena arising in such models in the state and parameter spaces as they interact. Results for the algebraically constrained systems are almost complete [68], [72]. Recently the theory has been extended to incorporate the effects of hard constraints in the form of various hard limits and has been presented in [84]. This part of the theory is substantially complete and the theoretical work is continuing on some aspects. There is significant progress on practical implementations by others [34], [48] and also by the authors who are analyzing very large scale actual disturbances encountered in the US system.
